comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
From the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website:

Name:COOKE, JOHN HOWARD
Initials:J H
Nationality:United Kingdom
Rank:Lieutenant
Regiment/Service:Army Service Corps
Unit Text:Mechanical Transport
Secondary Regiment:Royal Garrison Artillery
Secondary Unit Text:attd.
Age:25
Date of Death:09/10/1918
Additional information:Only son of William and Nancie Cooke, of The Thorns, Cheadle Hulme, Cheshire.
Casualty Type:Commonwealth War Dead
Grave/Memorial Reference:IV. C. 18.
Cemetery:TOURGEVILLE MILITARY CEMETERY

comment.author: 8498561@N08
comment._content:
Lt John Howard Cooke was born near Stockport in 1893, the only son of William & Nancie Cooke.
Gazetted to the 9th Bn Manchester Regiment as a Second Lt as of 14th November 1914.
Gazetted to the Army Service Corps as a Temporary Lt 19th June 1916.
Arrived in France on 11th August 1916.
Mother applied for his medals (BWM & VM) on 18th Febuary 1920. 
John is commemorated on the Cheadle Hulme War Memorial.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: FreeBMD Cooke John Howard birth reg 1st qr 1893 Stockport 8a 100 Stockport spans the boundaries of the counties of Cheshire and Lancashire John's cousin Captain Herbert Henry Nidd MC 1/7th Battalion MANCHESTER REGIMENT (16 July 1877 - 4 March 1919) is also listed on the Cheadle Hulme Memorial. 'At some point, whilst he was a boy, he went to live with the Cookes and was regarded as a son.'. Full story of Herbert here www.stockport1914-1918.co.uk/soldier.php?name_id=1910
